questions.q: What is the priority assessment for a depressed client?
questions.rationale: Safety is always #1. You must ask directly: "Do you have a plan to harm yourself?"

questions.q: What behavior indicates high suicide risk?
questions.rationale: Sudden peace or happiness often means the client has made the decision to end their life.

questions.q: When are restraints legally acceptable?
options: Only when client is a danger to self/others
questions.rationale: Restraints are a last resort for safety only; convenience or punishment constitutes false imprisonment.

questions.q: What is the nurse's task in the Pre-interaction phase?
questions.rationale: Before seeing the patient, the nurse must identify personal biases or fears to ensure objectivity.

questions.q: When should the termination phase be discussed?
questions.rationale: Setting the timeline early prevents dependency and prepares the client for the eventual end of the relationship.

questions.q: What occurs during the Working phase?
questions.rationale: This is where the therapeutic work happens: tackling issues, learning coping skills, and changing behavior.

questions.q: What is the goal of the Termination phase?
questions.rationale: Termination focuses on reviewing achievements and closure. Bringing up new deep issues here is inappropriate.

questions.q: Why should "Why" questions be avoided?
questions.rationale: "Why" demands an explanation and implies criticism, often making the patient defensive. Use "Tell me about..." instead.

questions.q: How should you handle a new OCD client's ritual?
options: Allow time for it, then set limits later
questions.rationale: Stopping a ritual causes panic. Initially allow it to build trust, then gradually limit time/frequency.

questions.q: What is the treatment for phobias?
questions.rationale: Gradual exposure to the feared object (desensitization) helps the client learn to manage anxiety.

questions.q: What is a classic sign of Anorexia Nervosa?
questions.rationale: Severe starvation causes the body to grow fine hair (lanugo) for warmth and stops menstruation (amenorrhea).

questions.q: What physical sign is common in Bulimia?
questions.rationale: Frequent vomiting bathes the teeth in stomach acid, eroding enamel.

questions.q: What is the best diet for a Manic client?
questions.rationale: Manic clients won't sit to eat. Portable, high-energy foods (sandwiches, shakes) prevent starvation.

questions.q: What activity is best for a severely depressed client?
options: Simple tasks with staff (e.g., folding laundry)
questions.rationale: Depressed clients need low-pressure interaction. Solitary activities increase isolation; competition causes anxiety.

questions.q: What is the difference between a delusion and a hallucination?
options: Delusion is a thought; Hallucination is sensory
questions.rationale: A delusion is a fixed false belief (I am Jesus). A hallucination is a false sensory perception (hearing voices).

questions.q: How do you feed a paranoid client who thinks food is poisoned?
options: Taste it in front of them
questions.rationale: Sealed food allows the client to see it hasn't been tampered with, building trust.

questions.q: Why are command hallucinations dangerous?
options: They tell the client to harm self/others
questions.rationale: Voices commanding violence are a psychiatric emergency requiring immediate intervention.

questions.q: When do Delirium Tremens usually start?
questions.rationale: DTs are the severe, life-threatening stage of withdrawal (seizures, hallucinations) peaking day 2-3.

questions.q: What prevents Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome?
questions.rationale: Chronic alcoholics lack B1, causing permanent brain damage. Thiamine is standard protocol.

questions.q: What electrolyte interacts with Lithium?
questions.rationale: Low sodium levels cause the kidneys to retain Lithium, leading to toxicity. Maintain normal salt intake.

questions.q: What is Displacement?
options: Shifting anger to a safer target
questions.rationale: Example: Kicking the dog because you're mad at your boss. Shifting emotion to a less threatening object.

questions.q: What defines Projection?
options: Attributing one's own faults to others
questions.rationale: Projection is taking your own unacceptable feelings (I hate him) and putting them on someone else (He hates me).

questions.q: How do you treat Denial in substance abuse?
questions.rationale: For abuse, you must point out the difference between what they say and what they do. (Note: Support denial in grief/loss).

questions.q: What is the key intervention for manipulation?
questions.rationale: Manipulative clients try to split staff. All staff must enforce the same rules firmly.

questions.q: Which condition is acute and reversible?
questions.rationale: Delirium has a sudden onset due to a medical cause (infection, drug) and clears when treated.

questions.q: What is a major side effect of Thorazine?
questions.rationale: Phenothiazines cause EPS (tremors, rigidity) resembling Parkinson's.

questions.q: What foods must be avoided with MAOIs?
questions.rationale: Tyramine causes a hypertensive crisis. Avoid BAR: Bananas, Avocados, Raisins (and organ meats).

questions.q: What is the primary use for Valium/Ativan?
questions.rationale: Benzos work quickly to reduce anxiety but are addictive.

questions.q: What lab must be monitored weekly for Clozaril?
questions.rationale: It destroys white blood cells, leaving the patient defenseless against infection.
